channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine’s Sudden Gains Prompt New Questions for Commanders
item.description: Ukraine’s military is gauging how far its forces can press the attack, at risk of their ability to hold the new lines. Russian leaders are trying to regroup after a dramatic, demoralizing rout.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier standing atop an abandoned Russian tank near a village on the outskirts of Izium in eastern Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Critics Speak Out, Prompted by Ukraine Losses
item.description: Ukraine’s recent battlefield successes are emboldening Vladimir Putin’s critics and sending his supporters in search of someone else to blame.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Russian tank abandoned in a village on the outskirts of Izium, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: King Charles Pays Tribute to Queen Elizabeth on a Day Steeped in Tradition
item.description: King Charles III addressed Parliament in London, then flew to Scotland for a service of thanksgiving for his mother.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The narrow streets of Edinburgh were thronged on Monday by well-wishers hoping to get a glimpse of the hearse carrying Queen Elizabeth II from Holyroodhouse to St. Giles’ Cathedral.

item.title: Oppressive Blackouts Force Lebanese to Change Rhythm of Life
item.description: With electricity coming on at random times, and for only an hour or two a day, residents have had to find coping strategies — including doing laundry and charging everything they can after midnight.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Laura Boushnak
item.media:description: Hasmik Tutunjian, 66, sitting in the dark using rechargeable lights in her apartment during power cuts last month in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Ukraine Claims More Ground in Northeast and South
item.description: Questions remained about how far Ukrainian forces could go without being overstretched as Russia’s retreat from the Northeast region prompts a rare public debate back home.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians extinguishing a fire after a rocket hit Kharkiv on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Sudden Success Could Bolster Europe’s Support — and Morale
item.description: “It’s not for nothing.” Ukraine’s backers say that an offensive over the weekend shows Western military aid is helping, and that it’s time to supply more sophisticated weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: After the village of Udy in the Kharkiv region was retaken by Ukraine, mines and other weapons were recovered.

item.title: Prime Minister Liz Truss’s Dizzying First Week
item.description: Ms. Truss took over a British government facing an economic emergency. But those problems have been eclipsed by the queen’s death, an epochal event that has put politics on hold.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss speaking outside 10 Downing Street last Thursday, the day Queen Elizabeth II died in Scotland.

item.title: Pakistan Is Devastated by Floods, Faces Looming Food Crisis
item.description: The flooding has crippled Pakistan’s agricultural sector, battering the country as it reels from an economic crisis and double-digit inflation that has sent the price of basics soaring.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Navigating floodwaters in the Dadu district of Sindh Province, of Pakistan, on Thursday.

item.title: Anti-Monarchists Tread Lightly After Queen’s Death, but Their Goal Persists
item.description: King Charles III is less popular than his mother, offering republican campaigners their best chance of momentum in years. But they risk offending mourners by moving too soon.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III greeting crowds on the Mall on Saturday in London after returning from Scotland, where his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, died last week.

item.title: Russia’s Retreat in Ukraine Pokes Holes in Putin’s Projection of Force
item.description: Russia’s military setbacks may be weakening President Vladimir V. Putin’s reputation at home as a savvy geopolitical strategist.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The scene in the Kharkiv region this weekend after Russian forces retreated.

item.title: Sweden’s Divisive Election Is Too Close to Call, Officials Say
item.description: The tight race capped a campaign that analysts called unusually aggressive, with the nationalist, right-wing Sweden Democrats increasingly popular.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A polling center at Royal College of Music in Stockholm on Sunday.

item.title: With Queen Gone, Former Colonies Find a Moment to Rethink Lasting Ties
item.description: In Commonwealth nations with British colonial histories, Queen Elizabeth’s death is rekindling discussions about a more independent future.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Tim Graham Photo Library via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in Tuvalu during a 1982 tour of the South Pacific, which also included a stop in the Solomon Islands.

item.title: Queen’s Ties to Scotland Add New Wrinkle to Push for Independence
item.description: Political analysts said that respect for the queen and her devotion to Scotland could strengthen a union that has been under acute strain for more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Watching the hearse carrying the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II, draped in the Royal Standard of Scotland, in Edinburgh on Sunday.

item.title: Charles to Visit Northern Ireland Before Queen’s Coffin Arrives in London
item.description: The new monarch will continue his tour of the nations of the United Kingdom on Tuesday, before meeting his mother’s coffin at Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III, with honor guards and other members of the royal family, holding a vigil at the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II at St Giles’ Cathedral, Edinburgh, on Monday.

item.title: Kenya to Inaugurate William Ruto as President, but Kenyan Television Is Mostly Shut Out
item.description: After a bitter and close election, William Ruto takes the reins of power on Tuesday. One of his team’s first moves: Limiting the access of local television outlets to the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: President-elect William Ruto of Kenya with his wife, Rachel, in the capital, Nairobi, earlier this month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: More Ukrainian advances.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: King Charles Inherits Riches, and Passes Off His Own Empire
item.description: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III spent years turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Advance Continues
item.description: Plus former British colonies weigh their relationship with the monarchy and Lebanon faces blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services responded to multiple missile strikes on a Ukrainian police station in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: What to Expect as Britain Mourns Queen Elizabeth
item.description: Her funeral is scheduled for Sept. 19. Before that, there are processions, vigils and four days of lying in state in London.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The queen’s coffin spent Sunday night at the Palace of Holyroodhouse, the sovereign’s official residence in Scotland.

item.title: At 75, the Father of Environmental Justice Meets the Moment
item.description: The White House has pledged $60 billion to a cause Robert Bullard has championed since the late seventies. He wants guarantees that the money will end up in the right hands.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.category: White House Council on Environmental Quality
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Bullard doesn’t recall when people started calling him the father of environmental justice. “It’s really a compliment,” he said. “I’ve been called worse.”

item.title: Biden Will Attend Queen Elizabeth II’s Funeral. Putin Will Not.
item.description: Heads of state and royalty from around the world are expected to attend the funeral on Sept. 19.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will be held at 11 a.m. next Monday at Westminster Abbey.

item.title: Losses in Ukraine Prompt Debate on Russian TV
item.description: The divergence of views, even on tightly-controlled state television networks, highlighted how Moscow’s narrative had quickly shifted.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin appeared on television at a bar in Moscow in February, before the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: What Is a Constitutional Monarchy?
item.description: Even without a written constitution, Britain follows laws and carefully documented traditions that together bind the king.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III on Monday in London’s Westminster Hall. He pledged to uphold Britain’s constitutional monarchy.

item.title: The Cowboy and Queen Elizabeth
item.description: A renowned American horse trainer described his three-decade-long friendship with Queen Elizabeth II, and the time she called him, unexpectedly, at 2:30 a.m.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
The Man Who Listens to Horses (Book)
item.media:credit: David Butow for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Roberts and a photo of the queen. “When the queen was with horses, she was a horse person,” he said.

item.title: New Zealand’s Leader Affirms Support for a Republic, but Not Now
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern previously said King Charles III had “consistently demonstrated his deep care for our nation.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand at a proclamation-of-accession ceremony for King Charles III in Wellington on Sunday.

item.title: How Long Is the Drive to the Edge of the Universe?
item.description: See you in a quadrillion years or so. Don’t forget to pack zillions of tons of snacks!
item.dc:creator: Randall Munroe

item.title: U.N. Agency, Ukraine and Russia in Talks to End Fighting at Nuclear Plant
item.description: The nuclear complex in southern Ukraine has been imperiled by frequent shelling, raising fears of a nuclear catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Gross of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna on Monday. He said Russia and Ukraine “were engaging with us” over talks to end fighting at the nuclear plant.

item.title: Prince Andrew Will Join Queen’s Memorial Ceremonies in Civilian Dress
item.description: The palace said the prince, largely exiled from public life over his ties to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, would mourn his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, in civilian clothes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Andrew viewing the messages and flowers left for Queen Elizabeth II at Balmoral Castle in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, on Saturday.

item.title: 18 Russian Municipalities in Moscow Call For Putin’s Resignation
item.description: The elections were an early test of whether the upheaval caused by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has affected voters.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A woman holding a ballot during municipal elections at a polling station in Moscow on Friday.

item.title: Are the Polls Wrong Again?
item.description: Are Democrats again about to be disappointed by overly optimistic polling?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station in Miami Beach, Fla.

item.title: Prince Harry Pays Tribute to Queen Elizabeth, His ‘Granny’
item.description: In his first public comments since the death of his grandmother, the prince said she was already “sorely missed.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, viewing flowers left in memory of Queen Elizabeth II outside Windsor Castle on Saturday.

item.title: Cracking the Case of the Giant Fern Genome
item.description: Scientists have sequenced complete fern genomes for the first time, to learn why the plants have twice as much DNA as humans.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: When the genome of the flying spider monkey tree fern was decoded in May, it was only the third time a fern’s DNA had been completely mapped, and the first time with a fern whose genome was so large.

item.title: Monkeypox Shots, Treatments and Tests Are Unavailable in Much of the World
item.description: High-income countries snapped up vaccines when the disease hit them, leaving none for countries that have battled the virus for years, in an echo of the Covid response.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A monkeypox sore on a patient’s foot at the Arzobispo Loayza Hospital in Lima, Peru, last month.

item.title: The Cartoonist Kate Beaton Found Humor, and Humanity, in Canada’s Oil Fields
item.description: Kate Beaton headed to the tar sand fields of Alberta saddled with loans and in need of cash. She found a job — and the book she “was always going to make.”
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito
item.category: Ducks: Two Years in the Oil Sands (Book)
item.media:credit: Paul Atwood for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kate Beaton in her home office, in Mabou, Cape Breton, in Nova Scotia.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: An embarrassing Russian retreat.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Kharkiv region this weekend after Russian forces retreated.

item.title: Ukraine Routs Russian Forces in Northeast, Forcing a Retreat
item.description: Russia acknowledged that it had lost nearly all of the northern region of Kharkiv after a blitzkrieg thrust by Ukrainian fighters.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The Kharkiv region this weekend after Russian forces retreated.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Ukraine Gains Ground
item.description: Plus China locks down Xinjiang and floods devastate Pakistan’s agriculture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: All the Beauty and the Bloodshed (Movie)
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer cleaned up debris at the Misto entertainment complex, which was hit by artillery two days earlier in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Strikes Cause Blackouts as Ukraine Gains in Northeast
item.description: Kyiv condemned the strikes as an act of revenge as Russian forces retreat in the northeast.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters at an electric power station in Kharkiv on Sunday after a Russian strike.

item.title: Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson Will Take Queen Elizabeth’s Corgis
item.description: Prince Andrew, who had given his mother the two corgis she owned at her death, and his ex-wife, Sarah, Duchess of York, will care for the beloved pets.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II owned more than 30 dogs during her reign, but was particularly fond of corgis, like these two she walked in London in 1970.

item.title: After Sept. 11, the Queen Requested ‘The Star-Spangled Banner’ at Guard Changing
item.description: It was a break with tradition and a show of support to a grieving nation.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Mourners will be able to view the queen’s coffin in Scotland and London.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the public paying their respects to Queen Elizabeth II outside Windsor Castle on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Advance in Northeast Renews Pressure on Germany to Help
item.description: Many weapons Germany promised Kyiv have yet to arrive. Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government has not fully explained the delays.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany inspecting an antiaircraft gun last month at a military base in Holstein, Germany. Germany has promised to deliver 30 of the units to Ukraine.

item.title: Britain’s Mourning Rituals
item.description: Britons are surrounded by visible symbols of Queen Elizabeth II’s death but relatively reserved in their grief.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince William and his wife, Kate, with Prince Harry and Meghan yesterday.

item.title: Ukraine Begins Shutdown of Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant
item.description: External power has been restored to the plant, allowing engineers to move its reactors into a safer state, Ukraine’s nuclear regulator said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant during a visit by the International Atomic Energy Agency expert mission this month.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Coffin Is Moved From Balmoral Castle
item.description: Queen Elizabeth’s coffin made a six-hour journey through the Scottish countryside.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Russia says that a senior Chinese official expressed support for the invasion of Ukraine.
item.description: The comments are the clearest sign of support from China, which has preferred to stay on the sidelines and maintain ties with both Russia and Europe, without alienating either.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobylev/Tass Host Photo Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Li Zhanshu, the third-ranking member of the Communist Party of China, met last week with President Vladimir V. Putin in Vladivostok, Russia.

item.title: Just Bread and Noodles: China’s Covid Lockdown Distress Hits Xinjiang
item.description: With lack of food, medicine and other crucial supplies, residents of Yining are chafing under a monthlong pandemic shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Residents at a fruit stall last week in Urumqi, the capital of the Xinjiang region of China, in a photo provided by China News Service. People in Yining have complained they can’t get produce amid a long lockdown there.

item.title: Chinese Drones: The Latest Irritant Buzzing Taiwan’s Defenses
item.description: Drones are increasingly testing Taiwan’s capacity to respond to China's growing military pressure. Soldiers shot one down recently and are ramping up defenses.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: A drone being paraded through Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: Ukrainian Offensive Seen as Reshaping the War’s Contours
item.description: The fall of the strategically important city of Izium, in Ukraine’s east, is the most devastating blow to Russia since its humiliating retreat from Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Ukrainian fighter atop a tank in Kharkiv, in northeastern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Join William and Kate Outside Windsor Castle
item.description: Prince William, Princess Catherine, Prince Harry and Meghan all visited crowds gathered to remember the queen.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince William, Princess Catherine, Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, on Saturday at Windsor Castle outside London.

item.title: As Russians Retreat, Putin Is Criticized by Hawks Who Trumpeted His War
item.description: Russian bloggers reporting from the front line provide a uniquely less-censored view of the war. But as Russia’s military flails, these once vocal supporters are exposing its flaws, lies and all.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian military vehicle in Balakliya, in the eastern Kharkiv region, on Saturday.

item.title: King Charles III Is Formally Proclaimed to His New Role
item.description: Charles will spend much of the first 10 days of his reign leading his country in mourning the queen, whose state funeral will be held on Sept. 19 in Westminster Abbey.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: In a ceremony filled with pomp and process at St. James’s Palace, a royal residence near Buckingham Palace, King Charles III was officially proclaimed on Saturday.

item.title: How Ukraine Gained Momentum Against Russia and Took City of Izium
item.description: For months, Russia used the city of Izium as a way station to resupply and reinforce its troops in their campaign to seize the eastern Donbas region. With a northern offensive, Ukraine has retaken the city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A destroyed tank in Balakliya, in the Kharkiv region, on Saturday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Will Be on Sept. 19 at Westminster Abbey
item.description: On Sunday, Elizabeth’s coffin will be carried from Balmoral Castle, in the Scottish Highlands, on a roundabout six-hour journey to Edinburgh, via Aberdeen.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Queen’s Death Leaves UK Grappling With Its Sense of National Identity
item.description: A figure who embodied Britain, Elizabeth cast long shadow. She leaves behind a country unsettled by domestic crises and anxiety over its place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laying flowers outside Windsor Castle on Friday in tribute to Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Thousands of Sunflowers: Mourners Pay Tribute to Queen Elizabeth at Windsor Castle
item.description: “She was a ray of sunshine to so many people,” said Natalie Prince, a Windsor florist who said she had sold 8,000 sunflowers on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Mary Turner
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Darling Buds of Windsor was selling thousands of sunflowers to people mourning the queen.
